revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Ronnie Corbett | honorific_suffix = [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] | image = Ronnie-corbett.JPG | caption = Corbett in 2010 | birth_name = Ronald Balfour Corbett | birth_date = {{birth date|1930|12|04|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], Scotland | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|03|31|1930|12|04|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Shirley, London]], England | death_cause = [[Motor neurone disease]] | resting_place = [[Croydon Cemetery|Croydon Crematorium]] | occupation = Comedian, actor, writer, broadcaster | years_active = 1952–2013 | height = 5 ft 1 in{{cite news|title=Four candles tribute to Ronnie Corbett in touching Westminster Abbey service|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/07/four-candles-tribute-ronnie-corbett-touching-westminster-abbey/|accessdate=6 October 2017|work=The Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited|date=7 June 2017}} | spouse = Anne Hart
(1966–2016; his death) | children = 3 | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = United Kingdom | branch = [[Royal Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1950–1953 | unit = Film Unit | rank = [[Flying Officer]] | battles = | awards = }} }} '''Ronald Balfour Corbett''', [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (4 December 1930 – 31 March 2016) was a Scottish stand-up comedian, actor, writer, and broadcaster, best known for his long association with [[Ronnie Barker]] in the BBC television comedy sketch show ''[[The Two Ronnies]]''. He achieved prominence in [[David Frost]]'s 1960s satirical comedy programme ''[[The Frost Report]]'' (with Barker) and subsequently starred in sitcoms such as ''[[No – That's Me Over Here!]]'', ''[[Now Look Here]]'', and ''[[Sorry! (TV series)|Sorry!]]'' ==Early life== Corbett was born in [[Edinburgh, Scotland]], the son of William Balfour Corbett (1898–1974), a master baker, and his London-born wife Annie Elizabeth Corbett (''née'' Main; 1900–1991).{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/features/3633106/Family-detective.html |title=Family detective |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=23 June 2007 |first=Nick |last=Barratt |accessdate=12 January 2008}} He had a brother about six years younger, and a sister about ten years younger.{{cite episode|title=Desert Island Discs with Ronnie Corbett |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/desertislanddiscs_20071021.shtml |series=Desert Island Discs |serieslink=Desert Island Discs |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]] |airdate=21 October 2007}} Corbett was educated at [[James Gillespie's High School]] and the [[Royal High School (Edinburgh)|Royal High School]] in the city, but did not attend university.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-35934024| title = Ronnie Corbett, best known for The Two Ronnie, dies aged 85 |date = 31 March 2016 | accessdate = 31 March 2016 | publisher = BBC News}} After leaving school, he decided he wanted to be an actor while performing in amateur theatricals at a church youth club.{{cite web | url = http://www.itv.com/news/2016-03-31/its-goodnight-from-him-a-look-back-at-ronnie-corbetts-life/ | publisher = [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] | title = It's goodnight from him: A look back at Ronnie Corbett's life | date = 31 March 2016 | accessdate = 31 March 2016}} His first job, however, was with the [[Ministry of Agriculture]]. Corbett served his compulsory [[national service]] with the [[Royal Air Force]], during which he was the shortest commissioned officer in the British Forces.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/8217498/The-One-Ronnie-BBC-One-A-timeline-of-Ronnie-Corbetts-career.html|title=The One Ronnie, BBC One: A timeline of Ronnie Corbett's career|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=21 December 2010}} A former [[Aircraftman|aircraftman 2nd class]], he was [[commissioned officer|commissioned]] into the secretarial branch of the RAF as a [[pilot officer]] (national service) on 25 May 1950. He received the [[service number]] 2446942.{{London Gazette|issue=38960|date=4 July 1950|page=3454 |supp=y}} He transferred to the reserve (national service list) on 28 October 1951, thereby ending his period of active service.{{London Gazette|issue=39376|date=2 November 1951|pages=5782–5783 |supp=y}} He was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 6 September 1952.{{London Gazette|issue=39990|date=16 October 1953|page=5574 |supp=y}} ==Career== Following national service, Corbett moved to London to start his acting career. At {{convert|5|ft|1|in|m|abbr=on}} tall, Corbett was suited to playing roles younger than his years.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0179196/bio|title=Ronnie Corbett|publisher=IMDb|access-date=1 April 2016}} References to his height frequently cropped up in his self-deprecating humour. In one of his earliest stage appearances, he was billed as "Ronald Corbett" at [[Cromer]] in ''Take it Easy'' in 1956, with [[Graham Stark]]. He appeared in ''[[Crackerjack (TV series)|Crackerjack]]'' as a regular in its early days, one episode with [[Winifred Atwell]]. He had a walk-on in an early episode of the 1960s series ''[[The Saint (TV series)|The Saint]]'' (as "Ronald Corbett") and appeared in films including ''[[You're Only Young Twice (film)|You're Only Young Twice]]'' (1952), ''[[Rockets Galore!]]'' (1957), ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'' (1967), ''[[Some Will, Some Won't]]'' (1970) and the film version of the [[farce]] ''[[No Sex Please, We're British (film)|No Sex Please, We're British]]'' (1973). Corbett starred in the first London production of the musical ''[[The Boys from Syracuse]]'' (as Dromio of Syracuse) in 1963 at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], alongside [[Bob Monkhouse]].London Cast Recording. The Boys from Syracuse. Decca Record Company Limited, 1963. LK 4564. In 1965 he was in cabaret at ''Winston's'', [[Danny La Rue]]'s [[Mayfair]] [[nightclub]]. [[David Frost]] saw him and asked him to appear in ''[[The Frost Report]]''. Corbett was in the West End, playing Will Scarlett in [[Lionel Bart]]'s Robin Hood musical ''[[Twang!!]]''. It failed, leaving Corbett free to accept.[[#Corbett|Corbett]], pp. 5–7 It was while working at Danny La Rue's nightclub that Corbett met Anne Hart, who he was to marry that year. The marriage lasted 49 years, until he died. === With David Frost === Corbett first worked with [[Ronnie Barker]] in ''The Frost Report'' (1966–67). The writers and cast were mostly [[Oxbridge]] graduates from the [[Footlights]] tradition. Corbett said he and Barker were drawn together as two [[Grammar schools in the United Kingdom|grammar school]] boys who had not gone to university. The show was a mixture of satirical monologues, sketches and music. Corbett and Barker were beginning to be thought of as a pair. They appeared with [[John Cleese]] in one of the most repeated comedy sketches in British television: the ''[[Class sketch]]''. Corbett's height provided a key cue for both the visual humour and satirical value of the sketch, as he "looked up" to both Cleese and Barker's characters, and he got the [[punch line|pay-off line]]: "I get a pain in the back of my neck."{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/thefrostreport/ |title=BBC – Comedy – The Frost Report |publisher=BBC |accessdate=21 April 2010}} Continuing under Frost, Corbett starred in ''[[No – That's Me Over Here!]]'', a sitcom written by ''Frost Report'' writers [[Barry Cryer]], [[Graham Chapman]] and [[Eric Idle]] ([[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] 1967–70). Cryer and Chapman wrote two follow-ups: ''[[Now Look Here]]'' ([[BBC]] 1971–73) and ''The Prince of Denmark'' (BBC 1974). Corbett also appeared in ''Frost on Sunday'' (ITV 1968) and hosted ''The Corbett Follies'' (ITV 1969). He was a subject of the television programme ''[[This Is Your Life (UK TV series)|This Is Your Life]]'' in April 1970 when he was surprised by [[Eamonn Andrews]] while appearing on the ''Frost on Sunday'' programme.{{cite web |url=http://www.bigredbook.info/ronnie_corbett.html |title=Ronnie CORBETT (1930-2015) |author= |date= |website=bigredbook.info |publisher= |access-date=19 September 2016 |quote=}} === ''The Two Ronnies'' === Corbett's [[BBC]] television comedy show with Ronnie Barker, ''[[The Two Ronnies]]'', ran from 1971 to 1987. Barker and Corbett performed sketches and musical numbers. Corbett presented a monologue. Sitting in a large easy chair (emphasising his small size), and usually wearing a [[Lyle & Scott]] golfing V-neck sweater, he would stretch telling a simple joke over several minutes, often allowing himself to appear to lose his train of thought. ===Later work=== Corbett's best-known role away from ''The Two Ronnies'' was as the 40-something Timothy Lumsden, dominated by his mother, in the sitcom ''[[Sorry! (TV series)|Sorry!]]'' (1981–88).{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/03/31/ronnie-corbett-a-fine-comic-and-an-entertainment-treasure/ | work = The Daily Telegraph | accessdate = 31 March 2016 | date = 31 March 2016 | title = Ronnie Corbett: A fine comic and an entertainment treasure | first = Michael | last = Hogan}} In 1996, he appeared on the première of the short-lived BBC game show ''[[Full Swing (game show)|Full Swing]]'', hosted by [[Jimmy Tarbuck]].{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/mar/31/ronnie-corbett-obituary | work = The Guardian | title = Ronnie Corbett obituary | first = Stuart | last = Jeffries | accessdate = 31 March 2016 | date = 31 March 2016}} Corbett played Reggie Sea Lions in the film ''[[Fierce Creatures]]'' (1997), written by his former ''Frost Report'' colleague John Cleese. Corbett hosted the game show ''[[Small Talk (UK game show)|Small Talk]]'' and played minor parts occasionally since its end – such as Griselda in a television production of ''[[Cinderella]]'' in 2000, and reviving his armchair monologue routines for a weekly appearance in a stand-up show hosted by [[Ben Elton]]. In 2003, he appeared in advertisements for the [[Sky+]] [[digital television]] service alongside [[Alice Cooper]]. The premise was a running gag about their being happy housemates. In December 2004, Corbett appeared on the BBC news quiz ''[[Have I Got News for You]]''. In 2005, Corbett teamed up again with Ronnie Barker for ''[[The Two Ronnies Sketchbook]]'', comedy sketches from their original series with newly recorded linking material. Also in March 2005, Corbett appeared with comedian [[Peter Kay]] in the music video for the number one single "[[Is This the Way to Amarillo]]?" to raise money for ''[[Comic Relief]]''. Corbett is remembered for accidentally falling on the treadmill that was out of shot in the [[Chroma key|green screen]] video; however, he found the fall funny when played back, and it was kept in the final version. He performed in ''[[Children's Party at the Palace]]'' as Mr Tibbs, the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]]'s butler. [[File:Ronnie Corbett and Susie Silvey.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Corbett and [[Susie Silvey]] on the set of ''Sorry!'', 1980s.]] In 2006, Corbett played a hyper-realised version of himself in ''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'', caught taking drugs at the [[BAFTA Awards]].{{cite web | url = http://metro.co.uk/2016/03/31/his-best-moment-ever-do-you-remember-ronnie-corbetts-epic-cameo-in-extras-5786707/ | title = His best moment ever? Do you remember Ronnie Corbett's epic cameo in Extras? | first = Duncan | last = Lindsay | date =31 March 2016 | accessdate =31 March 2016 | work = Metro}} He also starred as himself in ''[[Little Britain Abroad]]'', in which [[Bubbles DeVere]] tried successfully to seduce him. He opened the centre in [[Cromer]], Norfolk, named after [[Henry Blogg]].{{cite web | url = http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/ronnie_corbett_dies_aged_85_1_4477965 | work = Eastern Daily Press | date = 31 March 2015 | accessdate = 31 March 2015 | title = Ronnie Corbett dies aged 85}} Corbett was the "castaway" in the [[BBC Radio 4]] show ''[[Desert Island Discs]]'' on 21 October 2007. He featured as a Slitheen in a ''[[Sarah Jane Adventures]]'' episode for [[Red Nose Day]] 2009. He had a television interview about his life on 7 November 2009 for ''[[Piers Morgan's Life Stories]]''. In February 2010, Corbett was in the [[John Landis]] thriller comedy ''[[Burke & Hare (2010 film)|Burke & Hare]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/news/18964|title=John Landis' 'Burke & Hare' Goes Behind Cameras!|publisher=Bloody-disgusting.com|date=4 February 2010|accessdate=26 October 2010}} In August 2010 he was a panellist in the [[BBC 1]] comedy show ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]''.{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p009dc0t | title = Did Ronnie Corbett Really Want Four Candles? | date = 13 August 2010| accessdate = 31 March 2016|publisher = BBC}} In the same month, he was the star of the [[Good Food|Good Food HD]] programme ''[[Ronnie Corbett's Supper Club]]'' with [[Rob Brydon]] and [[Steve Speirs]]. The show's premise was that the main guest of the programme must choose a meal as if it were their last, and Corbett would cook it for him/her and his other guest, while they chatted about the guest's past and their current/future projects. In December of the same year he starred in a one-off special, ''[[The One Ronnie]]''. From 2010, Corbett starred in the [[BBC Radio 4]] sitcom ''[[When The Dog Dies]]''.{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2010/may/03/when-dog-dies-ronnie-corbett | title = When The Dog Dies | work = The Guardian | date = 3 May 2010 | accessdate = 31 March 2016|first = Elisabeth | last = Maloney}} The series reunited him with Ian Davidson and Peter Vincent, the writers of ''Sorry!'' The series returned to BBC Radio Four for another three series.{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0435c85 | title = When the Dog Dies | publisher = BBC Radio 4 | accessdate = 31 March 2016}} Already an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE), Corbett was promoted to [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[2012 New Year Honours]] for services to entertainment and charity.{{London Gazette|issue=60009|date=31 December 2011|page=7 |supp=y}}{{cite news|title=Honour for Corbett|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16364855|work=BBC News|date=31 December 2011|accessdate=4 December 2015}} ==Personal life== On 30 May 1966, Corbett married actress and dancer Anne Hart; they had two daughters, actresses Emma and Sophie Corbett. Their first child, Andrew, had a heart defect and died at six weeks old at [[St Thomas' Hospital]], London. Corbett lived in [[Shirley, London]] for many years.http://www.croydonguardian.co.uk/news/14395356.Goodnight_from_him__Croydon_comedy_legend_Ronnie_Corbett_dies_aged_85/ He also had a home in [[Gullane]], to the east of Edinburgh in Scotland. He was a [[beekeeper]] and kept hives at his second home.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8183425.stm | title=Is urban beekeeping the new buzz? | publisher=BBC | accessdate=22 January 2012 | date=5 August 2009 | first=Peter | last=Jackson }} Corbett was a golfer and appeared in celebrity and [[pro–am]] events; in 2009, he made a documentary with [[Colin Montgomerie]] in which they played at [[Gleneagles Hotel|Gleneagles]].{{cite web|url=http://programmes.stv.tv/made-in-scotland/presenters/105170-ronnie-corbett-golf/ |title=Ronnie Corbett: golf |publisher=programmes.stv.tv |accessdate=21 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820201348/http://programmes.stv.tv/made-in-scotland/presenters/105170-ronnie-corbett-golf |archivedate=20 August 2009 }} A keen cricket fan, Corbett was also a president of the cricketing charity the [[Lord's Taverners]] (1982 and 1987).{{cite web|url=http://www.lordstaverners.org/past-presidents-1980-1989.htm |title=The Lord's Taverners |publisher=lordstaverners.org |accessdate=21 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330042113/http://www.lordstaverners.org/past-presidents-1980-1989.htm |archivedate=30 March 2010 }} He supported his local [[association football|football]] club, [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace FC]], as well as his hometown club, [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian FC]].{{cite news |title=Comedian Ronnie Corbett launches Welsh Premier League |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/19258982 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=12 January 2014 }} Along side his family, his great niece Holly and Rachel Corbett regularly joined him at his second home to look after his bees. In mid-2014, Corbett attended a party at [[10 Downing Street]] hosted by Conservative Prime Minister [[David Cameron]].{{cite news|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/2014/07/accept-it-embrace-it-conservatives-arent-cool/|title=Accept it, embrace it: Conservatives aren’t cool|date=5 July 2014|work=[[The Spectator]]|accessdate=2 April 2016}} In August 2014, Corbett was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to ''[[The Guardian]]'' expressing their hope that Scotland would vote to remain part of the United Kingdom in September's [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|referendum on that issue]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/aug/07/celebrities-open-letter-scotland-independence-full-text |title=Celebrities' open letter to Scotland – full text and list of signatories |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=26 August 2014}} ==Death== On 31 March 2016, Corbett died at the age of 85, at Shirley Oaks Hospital in [[Shirley, London]], surrounded by his family.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/ronnie-corbett-dies-ronnie-barker-comedian-quote-entertainer-quotes-two-sonnies-a6961376.html "Ronnie Corbett dies"], ''The Independent'', 31 March 2016. He was survived by his wife and two daughters. He had been diagnosed with [[motor neurone disease]] in March 2015.{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/31/ronnie-corbett-dies-aged-85|title=Ronnie Corbett, 'true great' of British TV comedy, dies aged 85|date=31 March 2016|work=Guardian|accessdate=1 April 2016}} [[John Cleese]] said that Corbett had "the best timing" he had ever watched.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/entertainment-arts-35705753 | title = Reaction to Ronnie Corbett death | first = Lauren | last = Turner | first2 = Keily |last2 = Smith |work=BBC News | accessdate = 31 March 2016 | date =31 March 2016}} Sir [[Bruce Forsyth]] said Corbett's death marked "one of the saddest days of my life". Rob Brydon, a close friend of Corbett, said that he was his "comedy idol".{{cite news |author=Olivia Blair |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/ronnie-corbett-dead-ricky-gervais-and-comedians-pay-tribute-to-the-two-ronnies-star-a6961496.html |title=Ronnie Corbett dead: Ricky Gervais leads comedians paying tribute to The Two Ronnies star |work=[[The Independent]] |location=London |date=31 March 2016 |accessdate=31 March 2016}} Corbett's funeral service, for family and friends, was held on 18 April 2016, at the St John the Evangelist Church near his home in Shirley.[http://news.sky.com/story/1680785/stars-say-goodbye-to-great-guy-ronnie-corbett Stars say goodbye to Ronnie Corbett] In tribute to one of his classic ''Two Ronnies'' comedy sketches, [[four candles]] were displayed at the back of the altar. He was cremated following a private service at [[Croydon Cemetery|Croydon Crematorium]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/apr/18/ronnie-corbetts-funeral-attended-by-stars-of-british-tvs-golden-age|title=Ronnie Corbett's funeral attended by stars of British TV's golden age|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 April 2016}} Mourners included Sir [[Michael Parkinson]], [[David Walliams]], [[Rob Brydon]] and [[Jimmy Tarbuck]]. [[Barry Cryer]], who worked with and first met Corbett 50 years ago, said, "I can't think of him without smiling... I'm here and tipping my hat to him."{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-36073888 |title=Stars attend Ronnie Corbett's funeral |publisher=BBC News |date=18 April 2016 |accessdate=18 April 2016}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 1952 || ''[[You're Only Young Twice (film)|You're Only Young Twice]]'' || Student || |- | 1953 || ''[[Top of the Form (film)|Top of the Form]]'' || Student || Uncredited |- | 1954 || ''[[The Million Pound Note]]'' || Photographer || Uncredited |- | 1956 || ''[[Fun at St. Fanny's]]'' || Chumleigh || |- | rowspan="2" | 1957 || ''[[After the Ball (1957 film)|After the Ball]]'' || Stage Entertainer || Uncredited |- | ''[[Rockets Galore!]]'' || Drooby || |- | 1962 || ''[[Operation Snatch]]'' || Soldier || Uncredited |- | rowspan="2" | 1967 || ''[[Casino Royale (1967 film)|Casino Royale]]'' || Polo || |- |''Monsieur Lecoq'' || || |- | rowspan="2" | 1970 || ''[[Some Will, Some Won't]]'' || Herbert Russell || |- | ''[[The Rise and Rise of Michael Rimmer]]'' || Interviewer || |- | 1973 || ''[[No Sex Please, We're British (film)|No Sex Please, We're British]]'' || Brian Runnicles || |- | 1997 || ''[[Fierce Creatures]]'' || Reggie Sea Lions || |- | 2010 || ''[[Burke and Hare (2010 film)|Burke and Hare]]'' || Captain Tam McLintoch || |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !Channel !Notes |- |1953 ||''[[Douglas Fairbanks Presents]]''|| Young Hooligan |[[NBC]] |1 episode |- |1955 || ''[[The Vise]]'' ||Chap |[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |1 episode |- |1957 || ''Sheep's Clothing'' || Valet | rowspan="2" |[[BBC One|BBC Television Service]] |7 episodes |- |1957–1958||''[[Crackerjack (TV series)|Crackerjack]]!''|| Himself |40 episodes |- |1963 || ''[[The Saint (TV series)|The Saint]]'' || Call Boy |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |1 episode |- |1966–1967 || ''[[The Frost Report]]'' || Various roles |[[BBC One]] |28 episodes |- |1967–1970 || ''[[No – That's Me Over Here!]]'' || Ronnie | rowspan="3" |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |25 episodes |- |1969 || ''[[Hark at Barker]]'' ||Announcer/Lord Rustless/Others |15 episodes |- | rowspan="2" |1970 |''[[Frost on Sunday (1968–1970)|Frost on Sunday]]'' |Himself |10 episodes |- |''[[Jackanory]]''|| Storyteller |[[BBC One]] |5 episodes |- |1970-1994 |''[[This Is Your Life (UK TV series)|This Is Your Life]]'' |Himself |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |3 episodes |- |1971–1973 ||''[[Now Look Here]]''|| Ronnie | rowspan="8" |[[BBC One]] |14 episodes |- |1971–1987 ||''[[The Two Ronnies]]''|| Himself & various characters |93 episodes |- |1971-1994 |''[[Christmas Night with the Stars]]'' |Host |3 episodes |- |1974 |||''[[Now Look Here#The Prince Of Denmark|The Prince of Denmark]]''|| Ronnie |6 episodes |- |1975-1977 |''[[Seaside Special]]'' |Himself |2 episodes |- |1981–1988 ||''[[Sorry! (TV series)|Sorry!]]''|| Timothy Lumsden |42 episodes |- |1991-1998 |''[[Noel's House Party]]'' |The Butler |17 episodes |- |1994–1996 ||''[[Small Talk (UK game show)|Small Talk]]''|| Host |52 episodes |- |1998-2000 ||''[[Timbuctoo]]''|| Narrator &
all characters except Giant Squeak |[[Nick Jr. (UK and Ireland)|Nick Jr]] |2 seasons |- |1998 ||''[[The Ben Elton Show]]''|| Himself |[[BBC One]] |8 episodes |- |2000 || Cinderella ''[[ITV Panto]]''|| Griselda (one of the Ugly Sisters) |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |TV special |- | rowspan="2" |2004 ||''[[The Keith Barret Show]]''|| Himself with his wife |[[BBC Two]] |1 episode |- |''[[Monkey Trousers]]''|| Various roles |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |TV movie |- | rowspan="2" |2005 ||''[[The Scottish Golf Show]]''|| rowspan="4" | Himself |[[STV (TV channel)|STV]] |1 episode |- |''[[The Two Ronnies Sketchbook]] '' |[[BBC One]] |7 episodes |- | rowspan="2" |2006 ||''[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]]'' |[[BBC Two]] |1 episode |- |''[[Little Britain|Little Britain Abroad]]'' |[[BBC One]] |Parts 1 and 2 |- |2006-2009 |''[[The New Paul O'Grady Show]]'' |Guest |[[Channel 4]] |4 episodes |- |2008 ||''[[Love Soup]]''|| Gordon Baxter | rowspan="2" |[[BBC One]] |1 episode |- |2008-2010 |''[[The One Show]]'' |Guest |2 episodes |- | rowspan="2" |2009 ||[[The Sarah Jane Adventures]]|| Ambassador "Rani" Ranius/Slitheen |[[CBBC (TV channel)|CBBC]] |Various episodes |- |''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' |Co-host |[[BBC One]] |1 episode |- |2009-2012 |''[[Piers Morgan's Life Stories]]'' |Himself |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |3 episodes |- |2009-2014 |''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'' |Guest |[[BBC One]] |3 episodes |- | rowspan="7" |2010 |''[[Ant & Dec's Push the Button]]'' |Himself |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |6 episodes |- |''[[Something for the Weekend (TV programme)|Something for the Weekend]]'' |Timothy |[[BBC Two]] |1 episode |- |''[[The One Ronnie]]''|| Himself | rowspan="2" |[[BBC One]] |One-off programme |- |''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'' |Guest |1 episode |- |''[[Ronnie Corbett's Supper Club]]'' |Presenter |[[Good Food (TV Channel)|Good Food]] |1 episode |- |[[The Rob Brydon Show]] | rowspan="2" |Guest |[[BBC Two]] |1 episode |- |''[[Loose Women]]'' | rowspan="2" |[[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] |1 episode |- |2011||''Ronnie Corbett's Comedy Britain'' |Himself |Documentary |- |2013||''Ronnie's Animal Crackers'' |Presenter |[[BBC One]] |6 episodes |} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book | last1=Corbett |first1=Ronnie |last2=Nobbs |first2=David |authorlink2=David Nobbs| title=And It's Goodnight From Him ... | publisher=Michael Joseph, Penguin | year=2006 | isbn=0-7181-4964-5|ref=Corbett}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} * {{IMDb name|179196}} * [http://goodfood.uktv.co.uk/search/?q=ronnie+corbett&page=1 Ronnie Corbett's Supper Club] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Corbett, Ronnie}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish male actors]] [[Category:21st-century Scottish male actors]] [[Category:British sketch comedians]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Deaths from motor neuron disease]] [[Category:Disease-related deaths in England]] [[Category:Male actors from Edinburgh]] [[Category:People educated at James Gillespie's High School]] [[Category:People educated at the Royal High School, Edinburgh]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:Scottish humorists]] [[Category:Scottish male comedians]] [[Category:Scottish male film actors]] [[Category:Scottish male television actors]] [[Category:Scottish people of English descent]] [[Category:Scottish television personalities]] [[Category:British male comedy actors]]
